posts.author: comrade_skade
posts.content:
"I'm Annie... Annie Hoke. From the House of Plenty in Shadowdale."

Ivan Blaine looked the half-orc woman up and down as she curtsied, and tried not to sneer. She had drab green skin, slick greenish-black hair, and a face like a potato with ears. Her voice was sweet enough, for a half-orc; but Ivan could tell the minute she spoke that keeping it that way took effort.

The Chaunteans were already not Ivan's favorite - too stick-in-the-mud, most of the priestesses didn't even flirt - but this was an exceptionally grim omen for the job.

"Duke Mourngrym said he'd also be sending a Harper. Where is he?"

"That's me, sir."

"You?" This time Ivan could not help sneering.

"Yes, sir. I'm an ordained priestess of Chauntea, and also apprenticed as a Harper scout."

"I don't believe you."

"You're welcome to begin the raid without me, then." Annie's voice shook despite the half a foot and hundred-odd pounds she had over Ivan, but she gave the ultimatum forcefully. She did not sound like she would back down.

Ivan looked past the half-orc's shoulder, through the oaks and maples cushioning the north road, trying to make out the silhouette of Castle Krag. That kid from Shadowdale might have been spinning tales. That stuff about fighting a demon from the plane of Shadow and being rescued by Elminster himself? That sounded fishy, and Ivan knew - from bitter experience - that most "heroes" were egotistical liars. There might not be a lich in there. There might not be anything but rusty old spears, cold forges, and the bones of Annie's brethren.

Still... if there was a lich in there. On the off chance there was, he and Teurid needed a priest, or they would be screwed.

"Alright, fine. You get to be both our priest and our Harper delegation." Ivan looked over his shoulder at his companion, propped up snoring against a tree trunk. "Rid? You approve?"

Teurid opened one eye and glanced about. "Yah. Seems a'ight."

"You haven't even looked at her."

"Priests don' need to look good, mate."

"Isn't that how they turn undead?"

"Tha's a myf... myfth... myth."

"Is he alright?"

Ivan turned back to Annie. She had a doubtful look on her great big turnip face.

"Just drunk."

"Shouldn't we..."

"Wait for him to sober up? Nah, he can hit a mouse at a hundred paces like this."

"What about when he's sober?"

"Then he can't hit the broadside of a barn. Now come on, get your prayer book out and get praying." Ivan looked up at the sky, the tree shadows growing long, the blue of late autumn afternoon just starting to dim. "We want to be done and out of here well before dark falls."

///

Annie, at least, seemed to be a real priestess; though perhaps not of Chauntea, or at least not a stickler for rules. She wielded a scimitar alongside her shield, not a mace or a sickle, and wrapped it in magical flames the way Chaunteans were supposedly forbidden to. Ivan was not a stickler for anyone's rules, though, and the fiery glow was a boon in Castle Krag's dark corridors. True, Annie looked even more hideous by firelight, but Ivan could always complain about that later. To a pretty young barmaid in a friendlier town. After, well after, getting out of this place alive.

Krag's courtyard had been full of orc skeletons. And those skeletons had risen to greet them, and Annie had not dispelled a single one. Ivan wondered. What kind of priestess wouldn't bother turning the most basic of undead? What kind of priestess claimed to be a Chauntean, but lit her sword on fire? What kind of priestess looked like a giant sack of green potatoes?

What if she was actually a Zhent? Wouldn't that be an interesting story to tell -

"Stop."

"Huh?"

"Trap." Annie gestured down in front of her. A line in the dust... a tripwire. She raised her hand and pointed along the floor, up the left wall, up to a straight, dark, and very narrow line in the ceiling.

"Back up." Annie backed up; so did Ivan, careful not to let her bump into him. "Keep backing up. Okay, stop." About fifteen feet. "Rid, hit that wire."

The elf grunted, pulled a dart from his belt - bows were a bad idea in these confines - and chucked it underhand. The dart followed a big, lazy arc and landed dead on the tripwire. Something snapped, loud and crisp.

Not even half a second later, two enormous blades scythed out of the walls, cutting back and forth over the tripwire with slick rushing sounds. Ivan shuddered to imagine the mess they'd have made of a person, even one in full plate. Those things looked heavy.

"Good eye," he grudgingly admitted.

"Tha's an easy one, though," Tuerid grumbled. "Another foot and I'd ha' seen. Bu' yah. Harper is as Harper sees."

Ivan grunted agreement. "Alright then. Let's get on with it."

///

The lich, as it turned out, caught them by surprise.

Deep in the heart of Castle Krag, there was a bridge over dark stagnant water, a strange white marble bridge that glowed with its own light. Mist swirled thickly over the water, and none of them could see where the bridge went - not even Teurid with his elven eyes.

"I can' see a damn thing past thirty feet," Rid slurred out. "Ivan, wha' you think?"

"Well, our lich hasn't shown up yet. Let's press on."

"Annie?"

Ivan shot Rid a disgusted look, but the elf didn't seem to notice.

"Hmm..." the half-orc woman seemed hesitant. "Yes. Let's keep going."

"You getting second thoughts?"

She sighed. "Always, sir."

Maybe she was just new to the priesthood, young and stupid. Good enough at magic, but green as... well, green as a half-orc. Maybe the House of Plenty were trying to cut costs.

"Let's go."

But the bridge ended at a wall, the same white marble with a big craggy hole in it. Rid poked at the hole with his foot, and wrinkled his nose. "Rust monster used t' live here. Weird. Someone killed it probably.'"

"So why -"

Ivan heard Annie gasp before he heard the soft whooshing of air behind him. He spun around. The mist was clearing, and rising over the bridge on a cushion of ghostly fire was -

"Shit!" The lich was approaching fast, and they had nowhere to run. Ivan could feel the thing's vile aura, little hints of laughing faces across his vision, unintelligible whispers in his ears. He grabbed for the potions at his belt, hands shaking to the rhythm of his chattering teeth. If he could just reach that little orange bottle, if Rid could resist the creature and get to his wands in time, if his stupid ugly priestess could just cast a decent turning -

But the last thing he witnessed, before sense abandoned him, was Annie bellowing like a mad bull and charging straight at the skeletal form, scimitar swinging in a wild brute arc of fire. Beautiful and doomed. He could almost have laughed.

///

Ivan came to his senses slowly. His eyes were closed, and his left cheek felt covered in drool. Something was rocking him back and forth, but not in a pleasant way. It felt... Thumpy? Like an army marching.

He opened his eyes. Purple evening sky and trees swaying. He felt a surge of nausea and shut them again.

Laughter somewhere behind. Teurid's. "Wish you'd seen'er, mate. Green girl fights like a gods-damn demon outta the Abyss. She just went laying into that thing, whooooo. Never seen anythin' like it in all my three hundred years."

Annie made a snorting noise somewhere above him. This wasn't so bad, he thought. Kind of like riding a horse side-saddle. A big fat green draft horse with a face like... like...

"I don't seem so ugly now, do I, sir?"

No, Ivan had to concede, she didn't. He could almost have laughed.

---

An experiment in building a half-orc cleric with martial weapons, full Tumble AC, and no XP penalty. There are a number of possibilities here, e.g you can compromise Cleric dispel resistance to get Greater Rage, but the best is probably just taking Cleric 26/HS 5/Barb 9. Cleric and full Tumble should already give you all you need, and of course she's playable from early on; it's hard for a martial Cleric not to be. Just find a safe place to buff, and maybe lean on summons. Main skills after your first Harper Scout level will be Concentration and Tumble dumps, with little room for anything else, so spell saves will suck for a while... But that is okay, that's what your buffs are for.

This is, obviously, a bit of an RP build. A more powergame-y variant would take Strength domain, with Extend Spell and Combat Casting instead of Power Attack and Cleave, and maybe let Tumble lag a bit before Epic levels so that Concentration can be kept up. If you really want to focus on buffs it might be better also to take as many Cleric levels as possible, to e.g. maximize the effect of the Resist Magic spell.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I enjoyed reading the story. It explains well where you want to go with the build.
HS is a fine alternative when you want a tumble prestige class, and SD or assassin are out of the question.
The alignment should be any non-lawful, non-evil, and Annie seems a bit on the chaotic side.
Taking Barbarian rather than Cleric on level 20 will give +1BAB, but delays slightly becoming undispellable.
How does she play? Is it like any other combat Cleric?
By the way, I edited in the ending str and wis abilities.

posts.author: comrade_skade
posts.content:
Thanks Mick. TBQH she plays about the same as other half-orc Clerics I've tried, i.e. a bit worse than clerics of other races. Half-orcs are fun for roleplay, but the net stat reduction hurts in the long run, especially the reduced Int. Likewise the feat starvation, and low Concentration without Expertise to fall back on, and the reduced saves from low Spellcraft. Elf is a much better choice for a Cleric/HS build, since you can just take longsword or rapier focus for CoT.

Good point about the BAB. I tend not to think too much about keeping it at the full 15 since a melee Cleric will use Divine Power for tough fights anyway, but yeah, every little bit helps.

posts.author: comrade_skade
posts.content:
Actually, I'm curious now why keeping BA at exactly 15 is a good thing. Looking at the charts here: https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Base_attack_bonus the same class mix should result in the same BAB at L40 as long as the BA is between 11 and 15. (Which we want so that we can exploit the Divine Power bug.)

Personally I think I'd rather get ninth circle spells earlier... To each their own I guess. Or am I misunderstanding how final AB is calculated?

posts.author: TheSquid
posts.content:
Usually it is recommended to keep BAB at 15 due to the fact that Divine Power counts towards the +20 cap to AB bonus.
Example: you have 21 BAB with 11 pre-epic. You cast Divine Power for +9. With Divine Favor, GMW, and Bless you reach +20 for a total of 41 AB. Now if you use Aid/Prayer/Battletide, you will get no more bonus to AB
If instead you have 25 BAB with 15 pre-epic, you cast Divine Power for +5. With Divine Favor, GMW and Bless you still get to 41 AB. The difference is that now you can still get up to +4 bonus from other sources (weapons with more than +5 enchantment, or your own spells).
I agree with your general point that you don't necessarily want to use your full kit in all fights, but if very strong weapons are available or if you think you will need every point of AB, it makes sense to aim for 15 pre-epic BAB.
On WoG, where I mostly play, I often go to 14 or even 13 in order to have better saves or whatever, but this is the trade-off.

posts.author: comrade_skade
posts.content: Ohhh I see. Thank you, that is edifying! I'll have to see if it makes a difference next time I run a Cleric/Rogue/CoT or such.
